info.game_comments:
David Madden game 18.

(Jimmy: We're in Washington, D.C., poking around in the nation's attic.)
(Cheryl: Artifacts from the vault of the Smithsonian, next on Jeopardy!)

jeopardy_round: FROM THE VAULTS OF THE SMITHSONIAN

(1, 1).clue: This get-well card was sent by second graders to David Vetter, known as this boy kept in a plastic isolation unit

(2, 1).clue: This "colorful" 1967 Van Morrison song made the presidential cut

(3, 1).clue: This term can refer to an American born in the 1950s, a certain ex-NFL QB, or a male kangaroo

(4, 1).clue: The top 22 of these fortune-telling cards are known as the major arcana

(5, 1).clue: 20th century year in which America celebrated the tercentennial of the Pilgrims' landing at Plymouth

(6, 1).clue: A stoutly made safe in which valuables are deposited

(1, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew gives the clue from the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C.)  Starting in 1960, people whose hearts beat too slowly could have a Medtronic one of these implanted; the Smithsonian has an early one

(2, 2).clue: Pres. Bush enjoys this John Fogerty song on his iPod that might remind him of his days as a baseball team owner

(3, 2).clue: You can see why kangaroos are classified as macropodents, referring to the size of these

(4, 2).clue: This alphabet is made up of 22 letters including Yud & Bet

(5, 2).clue: It's the year the small step seen here was taken

(6, 2).clue: To use physical force or coercion against someone

(1, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew gives the clue from the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C.) This inventor used a device that transmits a signal to a receiver  to look for the bullet in President Garfield's body

(2, 3).clue: "Danger Zone" by this singer might be more apt than his "Alive 'n' Kickin'" on Bush's iPod

(3, 3).clue: The marsupial represented by the most species is this New World beast, with the Virginia species the largest

(4, 3).clue: He was just 22 in 1962 when he won golf's U.S. Open

(5, 3).clue: U.S. troops hit the beaches of Normandy in this year

(6, 3).clue: A bridge-playing term, or a particular field in which someone has talent

(1, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew gives the clue from the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C.) This is part of the 1848 gold shipment shown to this president; he gave a report to Congress that kicked the Gold Rush into gear

(2, 4).clue: "The House Is Rockin'" by this Texas blues guitarist keeps the Prez rockin' through his jogging & biking

(3, 4).clue: Named partly for its temper, it's extinct on the Australian mainland but endures on an island

(4, 4).clue: In 1975 Junko Tabei became the first woman to scale Everest, 22 years after this New Zealander did it

(5, 4).clue: Vietnam, Laos & Cambodia all fell to the Communists in this year

(6, 4).clue: It can be a place of refuge or an area dominated by a group

(1, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew gives the clue from the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C.)  This bit of mold played its part in history when this London scientist  noticed it destroying a bacterial sample

(2, 5).clue: Several songs by this country music legend appear on the first iPod, including "He Stopped Loving Her Today"

(3, 5).clue: Common and hairy-nosed are types of this creature that looks like a Down Under woodchuck

(4, 5).clue: Begun in 1887 to raise funds for 22 different agencies, the Charity Organization Society is known as this today

(5, 5).clue: In this year Senator Henry Clay pushed for a compromise in his last big speech before the Senate

(6, 5).clue: One of the fundamental interactions between elementary particles binding them to a nucleus

(1, 1).clue: A 1972 earthquake destroyed most of the downtown area of this Nicaraguan capital

(2, 1).clue: He's got drive & loves the green

(3, 1).clue: I like it, Chuck; an orphan overcomes the odds, dig the "Bill & Nancy" angle... do it as a musical?  Are you nuts?!

(4, 1).clue: A must-have for the preppy look: this short-sleeve collared shirt, particularly one of the brand of the same name

(5, 1).clue: The first U.S. Secretary of the Treasury, he was also involved in an early political sex scandal

(6, 1).clue: Superman's cub reporter pal admits to fathering Mary-Kate & Ashley & they become known as the...

(1, 2).clue: This capital is surrounded by, but is not part of, the Flemish region of Brabant

(2, 2).clue: This athlete gets a kick out of Madrid

(3, 2).clue: More orphans?! & this book's start, "My father's family name being Pirrip"... not exactly "Call me Ishmael", Chuck!

(4, 2).clue: This sneaker brand was introduced by the U.S. Rubber Co. in 1916

(5, 2).clue: In 1991 "The Star-Spangled Banner" entered the Billboard Top 40 for the first time, sung by her

(6, 2).clue: A House majority leader goes ga-ga over Dylan's "big brass bed" occupant & earns the nickname...

(1, 3).clue: Until 1924 this Mongolian capital was called Urga

(2, 3).clue: This young gun drives the No. 8 car

(4, 3).clue: This Italian craftsman who died in 1960 titled his autobiography "Shoemaker of Dreams"

(5, 3).clue: He appointed former President William Howard Taft to the Supreme Court

(6, 3).clue: Goldie Hawn title character is promoted to Prime Minster under Victoria & becomes...

(1, 4).clue: (Christiane Amanpour of CNN delivers the clue.)  In 1992 I reported from the shores of this African capital when the U.S. military launched Operation: Restore Hope

(2, 4).clue: This rapper changed nicknames, but kept the same initials

(3, 4).clue: Uncle Ralph's OK... nice alliterative title for this... but Wackford Squeers is now Ford Sears; we get 2 product placements for 1!

(4, 4).clue: The name of this garment is the French word for "breeches"

(5, 4).clue: He's the troubled prodigy whose story is told in the 1996 film "Shine"

(6, 4).clue: Lady tennis legend is grouchy with the press & gets compared to an arthropod with delicious legs as...

(1, 5).clue: It's the home of Belarusian State University

(2, 5).clue: Before he joined the NBA in 2003, his mother took out a loan to buy him a Hummer

(4, 5).clue: Last name of French design team Marithe & Francois, known for their streetwear

(5, 5).clue: This Japanese-American professor of linguistics was a California senator from 1977 to 1983

(6, 5).clue: '70s Jim Hutton TV detective goes on '50s Jack Bailey TV weeper & is mortified to be named...

(0, 0).clue: This man who became a ruler in April 2005 is the great-nephew of the 1926 winner of the Pulitzer Prize for Drama
